questions.question:
Question 1: What is the minimum amount of proteinuria required to diagnose a patient with nephrotic 
syndrome?
questions.explanation:
The minimum amount of proteinuria required to diagnose a patient with nephrotic syndrome is 
3.5 g/day.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 7-year-old girl is brought with complaints of generalized swelling of the body and frothy 
urine. Urinary examination revealed grade 3 proteinuria and the presence of hyaline and fatty 
casts. There were no red blood cells in the urine. Which of the following statements about her 
condition is true?

options.a: IgA nephropathy is the likely diagnosis.
options.b: It is associated with low C3 levels.
options.c: No IgG or C3 deposition is seen on renal biopsy.
options.d: Alport syndrome is the likely diagnosis.

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario in this child is strongly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome due to 
minimal change disease (MCD). It is characterized by the absence of immune deposits on biopsy 
and histopathological examination. It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children (peaks between 2–6 years). Biopsy findings of MCD are as follows: • Light microscopy - glomeruli appear normal (hence called 'minimal change') • Immunofluorescence studies - no Ig or complement deposits 779 
Sold by @itachibot • Electron microscopy - diffuse effacement of foot processes of visceral epithelial cells 
(podocytopathy)

questions.question:
Question 3: A 10-year-old boy is brought for a follow-up visit. He was diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome 
3 months ago and had been started on a course of oral prednisolone. During the current visit, 
no improvement is noted with regards to facial puffiness and urine analysis reveals grade 3 
proteinuria. Mutations in all of the following are associated with this condition except:
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome. It can be caused 
due to mutations in the following components of the glomerular filtration barrier: • Nephrin, podocin - are molecular components of the slit diaphragm complex • Alpha-actinin 4 - is a component of the foot process cytoskeleton Megalin is not a component of the glomerular filtration barrier. It is present in proximal 
convoluted tubular cells. Mutations in megalin may lead to some proteinuria but not nephrotic 
syndrome because glomerular filtration of proteins is not affected.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 67-year-old man presents with sudden onset flank pain and hematuria. Ultrasound reveals 
enlargement of both kidneys. He is a known case of membranous nephropathy. What is the 
likely pathophysiology for his current presentation?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario in a patient suffering from membranous nephropathy, which is a type 
of nephrotic syndrome, is suggestive of renal vein thrombosis. It is due to the loss of antithrombin 
III (an endogenous anticoagulant) in urine. Renal vein thrombosis is most often a consequence of a hypercoagulable state. In adults, it is most 
commonly seen in patients with membranous nephropathy.

questions.question: Question 5: In a patient with nephrotic syndrome, all of the following are decreased except:
questions.explanation:
In nephrotic syndrome, there is an increase in fibrinogen levels. 780 
Sold by @itachibot The following proteins are increased in nephrotic syndrome: • Fibrinogen • Lipoproteins - due to increased synthesis The following proteins are decreased in nephrotic syndrome as a consequence of selective 
proteinuria: • Albumin - the largest proportion of protein lost in nephrotic syndrome. • Transferrin • Cholecalciferol-binding protein • Thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG) • Ferritin • Coagulation factors • Antithrombin III

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient with radiologically confirmed reflux nephropathy develops nephrotic-range 
proteinuria. What is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome due to a secondary cause (reflux 
nephropathy). Secondary nephrotic syndrome in adults is most likely due to focal segmental 
glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). FSGS is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is a podocytopathy, with 
degeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells and effacement of foot processes. 
Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis are seen due to the entrapment of plasma proteins and 
increased extracellular matrix deposition. FSGS is classified as follows: • Primary • Idiopathic FSGS • Secondary • HIV associated • Heroin addiction • Sickle cell disease • Obesity • Hypertensive nephropathy • Renal conditions • Focal glomerulonephritis (e.g. IgA nephropathy) • Renal ablation • Unilateral renal agenesis or renal dysplasia • Reflux nephropathy 781 
Sold by @itachibot • Inherited • Mutated proteins of the slit diaphragm - podocin, alpha-actinin 4, TRPC6 Electron microscopy of FSGS shows: • Diffuse effacement of the podocyte foot processes • Focal detachment and degeneration of the epithelial cells • Absence of electron-dense deposits

questions.question:
Question 7: Patients diagnosed with which variant of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis are likely to have 
the worst prognosis?
questions.explanation:
The collapsing variant of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is associated with the worst 
prognosis. 782 
Sold by @itachibot There are 5 variants of FSGS: • Collapsing variant - poor prognosis • Glomerular tip variant - good prognosis • Cellular variant • Perihilar variant • Not otherwise specified - most common Given below is a histological image of collapsing glomerulopathy showing the involvement of the 
entire glomerular tuft and proliferation of visceral epithelial cells.

questions.question:
Question 8: Given below is an electron microscopy image showing deposits in the kidney. What could be 
the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
783 
Sold by @itachibot The given electron microscopy image shows subepithelial deposits in the kidney which is 
suggestive of membranous nephropathy. The following electron microscopy image shows subepithelial deposits in the kidney. Membranous nephropathy is characterized by the diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary 
wall. It is due to the accumulation of deposits containing Ig along the subepithelial side of the 
basement membrane.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of facial puffiness and frothy urine. Given below 
is his renal biopsy findings. What is the likely diagnosis? 769 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and the histopathological image showing uniform, diffuse thickening of the 
glomerular capillary wall are suggestive of membranous nephropathy. 784 
Sold by @itachibot Membranous nephropathy is one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome in the 
adults/elderly. It is a chronic immune-complex-mediated disease. The following image of the glomerulus shows the characteristic spikes. The spikes are formed due 
to the presence of basement membrane material (have affinity to silver stain) in between the 
immune complex deposits (lack affinity to silver stain). 785 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: Mesangial deposits are seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Mesangial deposits are seen in the following conditions: • IgA nephropathy (Berger disease) • Henoch–Schonlein purpura • Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis • Lupus nephritis classes I and II • Resolving postinfectious glomerulonephritis 786 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: A 29-year-old man presented with complaints of blood in his urine. Urine analysis was 
positive for proteins and red cell casts. A renal biopsy was done as shown below. 
Immunofluorescence microscopy revealed granular deposits of C3 on either side of the 
glomerular basement membrane but was negative for IgG, C1q, and C4. What is the likely 
diagnosis? 770 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario, immunofluorescence findings, and the image showing proliferating 
mesangial cells and capillary endothelial cells are suggestive of membranoproliferative 
glomerulonephritis type 2 (MPGN type 2) or dense-deposit disease. The following image shows bright deposits scattered along capillary walls and in the mesangium 
by immunofluorescence microscopy with antibodies to C3. 787 
Sold by @itachibot This condition belongs to a group of disorders called C3 glomerulopathies and primarily affects 
children and young adults. It is associated with a dysregulation in the alternative complement 
pathway. It is clinically and morphologically similar to MPGN type 1 but pathogenetically distinct 
from it. In this condition, a circulating autoantibody called C3 nephritic factor is present, 
which stabilizes the C3 convertase enzyme. The stabilized C3 convertase enhances C3 activation 
and consumption causing hypocomplementemia. Patients will have consistently decreased 
serum C3 levels, but normal C1 and C4 levels. The prognosis is poor, with about half of these patients progressing to end-stage renal disease 
(ESRD).

questions.question: Question 12: What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given serum electrophoresis image?
questions.explanation:
788 
Sold by @itachibot The given electrophoresis shows hypoalbuminemia and increased alpha-2 globulin, which is 
classically seen in nephrotic syndrome.

questions.question: Question 13: What is the most common cause of primary nephritic syndrome?
questions.explanation:
IgA nephropathy (Berger disease) is the most common cause of primary nephritic syndrome in the 
world. Nephritic syndrome is characterized by: • Acute onset of hematuria • Urinalysis - red cell casts • Diminished glomerular filtration rate (GFR) (oliguria) • Mild to moderate proteinuria • Hypertension • Azotemia

questions.question:
Question 14: A 28-year-old man is being evaluated for hematuria after UTI. Histopathology showed 
mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation. The following finding is seen on 
immunofluorescence, which was positive for C3 and negative for IgG. What is the likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario, histopathology findings of mesangial widening and endocapillary 
proliferation, as well as immunofluorescence showing mesangial deposits are suggestive of IgA 
nephropathy (Berger's disease). It is the most common type of glomerulonephritis worldwide. It is characterized by recurrent 
hematuria/ nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangium. 
Patients generally present with gross hematuria after respiratory, gastrointestinal or urinary tract 
infection. 789 
Sold by @itachibot The systemic variant of IgA nephropathy is called Henoch–Schönlein purpura. It is a disorder of 
children which presents with similar renal manifestations with characteristic IgA deposits in the 
mesangium in about one-third of the patients.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 6-year-old child abruptly develops fever, oliguria, periorbital edema and smoky cola-colored 
urine 2-weeks after recovery from sore throat. His renal biopsy image is given below. Which 
of the following statements is false about the given condition?

options.a: A rapidly progressive form with oliguria develops in 50% of children
options.b: It is a form of proliferative glomerulonephritis
options.c: Granular IgG and C3 deposits are seen on immunofluorescence
options.d: Dome-shaped subepithelial humps are seen on electron microscopy

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology image showing hypercellular glomeruli are 
suggestive of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Rapidly progressive disease with 
oliguria is very rare (< 1% of patients). Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a type of diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis. It is 
usually preceded by an acute streptococcal sore throat or impetigo around 1-4 weeks prior. It usually presents with features of nephritic syndrome including: 790 
Sold by @itachibot • Hematuria • Red cell casts in the urine • Azotemia, oliguria • Hypertension • Mild to moderate proteinuria • Edema On microscopy, the following findings are seen: • Light microscopy - enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with influx of leucocytes (endocapillary 
proliferation) • Electron microscopy - subepithelial humps • Immunofluorescence - granular IgG and C3 deposits on glomerular basement membrane and 
mesangium Majority (> 95%) of affected children eventually recover renal function with conservative 
therapy.

questions.question:
Question 16: A pathologist is examining the following renal biopsy specimen. What does it show? 773 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Proliferating parietal and visceral epithelial cells and WBCs in Bowman space
options.b: Diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall
options.c: Proliferating mesangial cells and increased matrix deposition in the mesangium
options.d: Proliferation of capillaries with fibrin deposition

questions.explanation:
The given image shows a crescent-shaped mass of proliferating parietal and visceral epithelial 
cells and leukocytes within the Bowman capsule. It is a characteristic feature of rapidly 
progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) or crescentic glomerulonephritis. RPGN is a type of nephritic syndrome associated with severe glomerular injury with necrosis and 
formation of crescents. It is usually immune-mediated and may be associated with 
circulating anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs), anti-GBM antibodies, and antinuclear 
antibodies (ANA). 791 
Sold by @itachibot Injury to the glomerular capillary wall leads to the escape of procoagulant factors and cytokines in 
the Bowman space. This triggers: • Proliferation of glomerular epithelial cells - mostly parietal, but also some visceral cells • Recruitment of leukocytes and fibroblasts • Pathognomonic crescents - due to the circumferential accumulation of these cells and fibrin The crescents progressively compress the capillary tuft. This results in a rapid decline of 
glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and, consequently, acute kidney injury (AKI). Thus, the degree of 
crescent formation correlates with the severity and the prognosis of the disease.

questions.question:
Question 17: A patient with recurrent hemoptysis and renal failure underwent renal biopsy. It revealed the 
presence of crescents in most of the glomeruli. Immunofluorescence finding is shown in the 
image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario, histopathology findings, and immunofluorescence showing linear, 
dense, and smooth deposits are suggestive of Goodpasture's syndrome. 792 
Sold by @itachibot Goodpasture's syndrome is an anti-GBM (glomerular basement membrane) antibody-mediated 
disease. The antibodies are directed against the non-collagenous portion of the 3 chain of 
collagen type IV. As it is present in both the alveoli and GBM, it usually presents with pulmonary 
hemorrhage and renal failure. It makes up about 1/5 of cases of rapidly progressive 
glomerulonephritis. Crescents with linear deposits of IgG and C3 in the glomerular basement membrane are seen on 
histopathology. Note: Wegener's granulomatosis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis) causes the pauci-immune type 
of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. There is an absence of immune complex deposition on 
immunofluorescence.

questions.question:
Question 18: An 18-year-old otherwise healthy boy presents with complaints of hematuria. His father has 
also had similar complaints since childhood. Light microscopy of the renal biopsy specimen 
showed no abnormalities. Diffuse thinning of the glomerular basement membrane was seen 
on electron microscopy. What is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.question: Question 19: What is the most common manifestation of Alport's syndrome?
questions.explanation:
The most common manifestation of Alport syndrome is gross or microscopic hematuria, 
frequently accompanied by red cell casts. Proteinuria and oliguria may develop later in the disease, and rarely, nephrotic syndrome 
develops. The deafness may be subtle requiring sensitive testing. There are no significant light microscopy changes in Alport syndrome. On electron microscopy, 
the glomerular basement membrane shows: • Irregular foci of thickening, alternating with attenuation (thinning) • Pronounced splitting and lamination of the lamina densa - basket-weave appearance 794 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: A middle-aged male patient has proteinuria. Looking at the immunofluorescence image 
below, what is the diagnosis? 775 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given immunofluorescence staining of the kidney biopsy specimen shows positive staining for 
fibrinogen, IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3,  chain, and k light chain. This is known as full-house effect. It 
is seen in lupus nephritis.

questions.question: Question 21: Urinary albumin excretion of how much is considered as microalbuminuria?
questions.explanation:
Urinary albumin excretion in the range of 30–300 mg/24 hours is called microalbuminuria. It is 
the hallmark of early diabetic nephropathy. 795

questions.question:
Question 22: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed 
proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and 
cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis? 776 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology image showing acellular periodic acid Schiff 
(PAS)-positive nodules are suggestive of Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease. It occurs in patients 
with diabetic nephropathy. 796 
Sold by @itachibot The following renal lesions are encountered in diabetic nephropathy: • Glomerular lesions - • Capillary basement membrane thickening • Diffuse mesangial sclerosis • Nodular glomerulosclerosis/ Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease • Intercapillary glomerulosclerosis • Renal vascular lesions - hyaline arteriolosclerosis • Pyelonephritis - necrotizing papillitis Option A: In amyloidosis, glomerular deposits appear as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, 
forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid. Option B: In focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, there is focal and segmental hyalinosis and 
sclerosis of the capillary wall with lipid droplets in the sclerosed area. Option D: In lupus nephritis, immune complex deposits are seen in the mesangium or along the 
entire basement membrane (wire loop lesions), with mesangial cell proliferation.

questions.question:
Question 23: A 51-year-old male patient came with complaints of hematuria to the clinic. On examination, 
he was normotensive and had pedal edema. Investigations revealed the patient had no 
glycosuria and had a creatinine of 9. His renal biopsy is shown below. Which of the following 
investigations should be done to identify the disease? 777 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Based on the given clinical history and microscopy showing crescents, rapidly progressive 
glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is suspected. Among the given options, anti- GBM antibody 
testing should be done, since it is a part of the work-up of RPGN. 797 
Sold by @itachibot Type 1 RPGN includes renal limited disease and Goodpasture's disease. In this condition, 
antibodies are produced against the non-collagenous domain of the 3 chain of collagen IV of the 
GBM. Microscopy findings of Goodpasture's disease are: • Immunofluorescence - linear deposits of Ig and complement along the glomerular basement 
membrane • Electron microscopy - wrinkling of the glomerular basement membrane with focal 
disruptions without any immune complex deposition. A variant of Goodpasture's disease with pulmonary involvement is known as Goodpasture's 
syndrome. Option A: ANA testing is done if SLE is suspected. Electron microscopy will show immune 
complex deposits. 798 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: HIV RNA testing is done in immunodeficiency syndrome associated with weight loss. 
Electron microscopy will show diffuse podocyte injury with complete foot process effacement. 
Tubuloreticular inclusions will be seen in endothelial cells. Option D: Urine electrophoresis is done if nephrotic syndrome is suspected.

questions.question: Question 24: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is seen in HIV, SLE, CLL, and Hepatitis B. MPGN is caused due to immune-mediated injury. It often presents with a nephritic-nephrotic 
picture. The causes of MPGN are as follows: • Primary MPGN (Idiopathic) • Secondary MPGN • System lupus erythematosus (SLE) • 1-antitrypsin deficiency • Infections - hepatitis B, hepatitis C, HIV, schistosomiasis, endocarditis, infected ventriculoatrial 
shunts, chronic visceral abscesses • Malignancies - chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) MPGN is characterized by the proliferation of cells predominantly in the mesangium and the 
capillary loops. Hence it is also called mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis. There are 2 types of 
MPGN: • Type I - It is characterized by the deposition of immune complexes and mesangiocapillary 
proliferation. • Type II - It is now known as dense-deposit disease. It belongs to a group of disorders called C3 
glomerulopathies. Light microscopy findings of MPGN are as follows: • Lobular glomeruli with proliferating mesangial cells, capillary endothelium, and infiltrating 
leukocytes (endocapillary proliferation) • Duplication of the basement membrane gives a double contour or tram-track appearance. It 
is especially evident in silver or PAS stains. 799 
Sold by @itachibot 800 
Sold by @itachibot Tubulointerstitial, Vascular and Cystic Diseases
